revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Life Extension: A Practical Scientific Approach''''' is a 1982 book ({{ISBN|0-446-51229-X}}) by [[Durk Pearson]] and [[Sandy Shaw (writer)|Sandy Shaw]] that popularized the [[life extension]] and [[Nootropic|smart drug]] movements.See ''Rapture: How Biotech Became the New Religion'', by Brian S. Alexander, New York: Basic Books, 2003, {{ISBN|0-7382-0761-6}}, pp. 5–6.{{cite news |first=Katherine |last=Bishop |publisher=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] newspaper|title=FDA fears smart drugs could pose stupid risks |date=1992-06-11 |accessdate=2007-03-01 |url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:AWNB:SPIB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0EB04A057A2FC5B9&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated4&req_dat=0D0CB57AB53DF815 }} The book discussed [[Radical (chemistry)|free radical]]s and the idea that they cause aging, and how [[antioxidant]]s were said to partially prevent the damage they do.{{cite news| first=Dennis |last=Fiely |title='Biochemical bad boys' - Possible causes of disease, free radicals, may have met their match |publisher=Columbus Dispatch |date=1993-09-16 |accessdate=2007-03-01 |url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:AWNB:CLDB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=10E0DA583AA751E0&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated4&req_dat=0D0CB57AB53DF815}} The book suggests causes of aging and ways to slow them, with material on improving health and various aspects of the quality of life. One notable feature of the book was several full-page pictures of its male and female authors, Durk Pearson and Sandy Shaw, striking bodybuilding poses and showing off some impressive muscles for "sedentary research scientists," which they claimed was due to the "growth hormone releasers" they took daily. == Criticism == Medical health experts have dismissed Pearson and Shaw's life-extension formula as dangerous. The [[American Council on Science and Health]] reported that the risks of their formula included headaches, intestinal disorders and kidney damage.Renner, John H. (1990). ''HealthSmarts: How to Spot the Quacks, Avoid the Nonsense, and Get the Facts that Affect Your Health''. Health Facts Publishing. p. 80. {{ISBN|978-0962614507}} In the 1992 [[documentary]] ''Never Say Die: The Pursuit of Eternal Youth'', Antony Thomas interviewed Pearson and Shaw, and criticised the anti-aging movement as misguided.{{cite news| title=The often gruesome search for perpetual youth |first=Virginia |last=Mann |publisher=The Record newspaper|date=1992-08-17 |accessdate=2007-03-01 |url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:AWNB:BRCB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0EB2778DA83E3DCC&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated4&req_dat=0D0CB57AB53DF815 }} A review in ''[[JAMA (journal)|JAMA: The Journal of the American Medical Association]]'' by researchers with the Harvard School of Public Health advised that “Some of the "health" advice contained in this book would be humorous if it was not so dangerous” and that “Potential readers of this ridiculous book would be wiser to take only the antacids—as we felt the urge to do after the realization that we had spent $22.50 on an unscientific, impractical, and potentially dangerous health fraud that literally made us ill.”{{cite journal|last=Stare|first=Fredrick J.|author2=Aronson, Virginia |title=Life Extension: A Practical Scientific Approach|journal=JAMA|date=November 23, 1983|volume=250|issue=20|pages=2862–3|url=http://jama.jamanetwork.com/pdfaccess.ashx?ResourceID=526884&PDFSource=13|accessdate=2 June 2012|doi=10.1001/jama.1983.03340200094043}} [[Stephen Barrett]] of [[Quackwatch]] wrote that the advice in the book was impractical and unscientific. For example the authors recommended more than thirty supplements and prescription drugs and for the subject to take a medical examination with more than fifty laboratory tests. The authors made inaccurate statements about [[Multivitamin|vitamin supplements]] and their "presentation of experimental data is biased and uncritical."[https://www.quackwatch.org/04ConsumerEducation/NegativeBR/le.html "Book Review: Life Extension: A Practical Scientific Approach (1982)"]. [[Quackwatch]]. Retrieved November 22, 2018. Nutritionist Kurt Butler has described the book as a [[hoax]] and has written:
Pearson and Shaw denigrate exercise and claim that all its benefits can be had by taking the pills and remaining sedentary. Many experts believe that following their advice is more likely to accelerate aging rather than retard it. This is because the so-called antioxidants in their regimen are actually redox agents that act as pro-oxidants when taken in the doses the authors recommend, and because exercise is the best proven anti-aging tool available to us.Butler, Kurt. (1999). ''Lying for Fun and Profit: The Truth about the Media: Exposes the Corrupt Symbiosis Between Media Giants and the Health Fraud Industries''. Health Wise Productions. p. 85. {{ISBN|978-0967328102}}
[[Gerontology#Biogerontology|Biogerontologist]] Dr. [[Roy Walford]] wrote, "[[gerontology]] has always been the happy hunting ground for faddists, charlatans, pseudoscientific fringe characters, and just misinformed enthusiasts with 'ready cures' for aging. ... Pearson and Shaw are among this long list of enthusiasts. ... Most of the Pearson/Shaw book relies on this lower-order category of evidence, and upon the testimonial posturing of Pearson and Shaw themselves."{{cite book|last=Walford|first=Roy|title=Beyond the 120 Year Diet: How to Double Your Vital Years|year=2000|publisher=Four Walls Eight Windows|location=New York, NY|isbn= 9781568581576|pages=21–23|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I0GeWFLLbQEC&pg=PA21&lpg=PA21}} In a discussion group posting, biogerontologist Dr. Steve Harris, MD criticizes the book, offering an example of one the authors' "screwups:" :: I managed to track one of their references to the (supposedly) somniferous effects of inositol back through some of the primary literature they'd cited (loosely) in the back of the chapter. Wups, guess what? They'd been reading a paper on natural ligands of the benzodiazepine receptor, and confused inositol with inosine (helped out by [[Carl Pfeiffer (pharmacologist)| [Carl] Pffeifer]]'s [sic] claims that inositol is sleep inducing). Inosine actually HAS some demonstrated Valium like effects in some animals (birds), but to this day you're going to see inositol in sleep remedies.{{cite web|last=Harris|first=Steve|title=Re: Whats up with Pearson & Shaw|url=http://groups.google.com/group/sci.life-extension/msg/3ba7eb3669464c37|accessdate=2 June 2012}} == References == {{Life extension}} [[Category:1982 books]] [[Category:Dieting books]] [[Category:Life extension]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2017}} {{dynamic list|date=April 2015}} American singer [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], throughout her career, spanning three decades, has obtained a remarkable series of statistical achievements, setting and breaking several [[world record]]s with her participation in entrepreneurial activities, of acting and her performance in the musical scene for her [[Madonna videography|videos]], [[Madonna singles discography|singles]], [[Madonna albums discography|albums]], and [[List of Madonna concert tours|tours]].
Her first appearance in the ''[[Guinness Book of World Records]]'' was in 1986 with her third studio album, ''[[True Blue (Madonna album)|True Blue]]''. Since then, she has earned multiple appearances, some 20 at least in February 2012, including her insigne record title as the [[List of best selling music artists|top-selling female recording artist of all time]]. Madonna's commerciality has achieved scrutiny studies and analysis from different point of view in the [[academia]] world or by marketers, through her [[Marketing strategy|marketing strategies]], controversies and reinvention, surpassing to others new or [[contemporary]] artists. In [[popular culture]], many international artists have been called "[[Honorific nicknames in popular music|Madonna]]", many times, by their impact and success in their respective countries or genres. Also, her presence in popular culture, has been led to create world records about Madonna. Dubbed as the most successful and most influential female artist of all time,<ref name="WMA">{{cite web|url=http://www.worldmusicawards.com/index.php/news/how-madonna-changed-world/|title=How Madonna changed the World!|date=August 17, 2013|accessdate=April 11, 2015|work=[[World Music Awards]]}}</ref><ref name="cnn2008">{{cite news|first=Stephanie|last=Busari|title=Hey Madonna, Don't Give Up the Day Job!|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/SHOWBIZ/Movies/03/18/madonna.movies/?iref=mpstoryview|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=March 24, 2008|accessdate=April 11, 2015}}</ref> {{TOC limit|3}}

==== ''Billboard'' Hot 100 chart statistics ==== {{see also|List of artists by number of Billboard Hot 100 number-one singles}} {{Pie chart | thumb = right | caption = Madonna's number-one singles on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 | other = | label1 =1980s: 7 singles | value1 = 58.3 | label2 =1990s: 4 singles | value2 =33.3 | label3 =2000s: 1 single | value3 =8.4 }}
When she reached number one with "[[Music (Madonna song)|Music]]" in 2000 at Billboard Hot 100, it made Madonna the second artist to achieve number one hits on the Hot 100 in the 1980s, 1990s and 2000s.<ref name="JanetJackson">{{cite news|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fxEEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA100|title=Making Her Own Kind of Music|last=Bronson|first=Fred|date=September 16, 2000|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=March 13, 2015|page=100|issn=0006-2510|volume=112|issue=38}}</ref> Also, when she released "Who's That Girl" in 1987 it became Madonna's sixth number-one single in the United States, making her the first artist to accumulate six number-one singles in the 1980s, and the first female performer to get that many number-ones as a solo act.<ref name="ach">{{cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6229105/madonna-song-whos-that-girl-no-1|title=Flashback Friday: Madonna's 'Who's That Girl' Hit No. 1|last=Strecker|first=Erin|date=August 8, 2014|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=March 13, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/24660679.html?dids=24660679:24660679&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+21%2C+1987&author=Jan+DeKnock&pub=Chicago+Tribune+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=MADONNA+SOARS+TO+TOP+OF+THE+CHARTS+FOR+THE+SIXTH+TIME&pqatl=google|title=Madonna Soars to Top of the Charts for the Sixth Time|date=August 22, 1987|author=DeKnock, Jan|work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=March 13, 2015}}</ref> In 2012, with "[[Give Me All Your Luvin']]" she became the second female with highest number of ''Billboard'' Hot 100 singles by female artists, only behind [[Aretha Franklin]]. The song is her 56th appearance on the chart.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.yahoo.com/music/bp/week-ending-feb-5-2012-songs-madonna-mj-024543065.html|title=Week Ending Feb. 5, 2012. Songs: Madonna & MJ|author=Paul Grein|date=February 8, 2012|accessdate=March 7, 2015|publisher=[[Yahoo!]]}}</ref> In 1991, with "[[Rescue Me (Madonna song)|Rescue Me]]" when it debuted at No. 15 on the March 2, 1991 Hot 100 chart, it marked the highest-ever bow for a single by a woman. Further, it was —at the time— one of only four titles to debut in the top 20.<ref name="40Biggest">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/list/499398/madonnas-40-biggest-billboard-hits|title=Madonna's 40 Biggest Billboard Hits|date=March 2, 2015|accessdate=March 7, 2015|work=Billboard|author=Keith Caulfield}}</ref> Madonna is the third oldest female to place a number one at the Billboard Hot 100. The single "Music" reached the number-one spot when Madonna was forty-two years one month old (September 2000). She holds the record with 38 singles within the Top 10, most for any artist.<ref name="40Biggest"/><ref name="recordTop10"/>

She has 46 number-one songs in the chart —the most for any artist.<ref name="danceone" /><ref name="USDance42">{{cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/chartbeat/497029/madonna-notches-42nd-no-1-on-danceclub-play-songs|title=Madonna Notches 42nd No. 1 on Dance/Club Play Songs|author=Gary Trust|date=April 9, 2012|accessdate=March 30, 2015|work=Billboard}}</ref> Also, is the only active artist to chart continuously since 1982, spanning four decades. ''Billboard'' said: "comparing her chart champs by decade, Madonna scored nine Dance/Club Songs No. 1s in the '80s and 13 in the '90s. Since 2000, she has almost doubled her total, adding 18 No. 1s in that span".<ref name="USDance40">{{cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/267393/celebration-madonnas-40-most-impressive-instants|title='Celebration': Madonna's 40 Most Impressive Instants|author=Gary Trust|date=September 15, 2009|accessdate=April 1, 2015|work=Billboard}}</ref> In 2012, when she release "Girl Gone Wild", became her 42nd No. 1 on the record chart, ''Billboard'' said that she has the quickest span of back-to-back No. 1s.<ref name="USDance42"/> Also, the magazine declared that "essentially, if Madonna releases a single and it charts on Dance/Club Play Songs, it's a safe bet to assume it'll go to No. 1. Since 2000, she's placed 26 hits on the survey. Of those, all but six have gone all the way to No. 1.<ref name="ElvisandMadonna">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/chartbeat/513469/elvis-presley-madonna-the-day-the-music-died-and-was-born|title=Elvis Presley & Madonna: The Day the Music Died, and Was Born|work=Billboard|accessdate=April 10, 2015|date=August 16, 2012|author=Gary Trust}}</ref> Also, Madonna is the only artist in history to achieve seven top-ten hits from one album (''[[American Life]]'') and the only artist ever to achieve seven consecutive number-one hits on this chart twice.
"[[Give Me All Your Luvin']]" set a record chart, when it debuted at 24 in the [[Hot Dance Club Songs|Dance/Club Play Songs chart]] and rose to 9 the next week, having the fastest rising to the top 10 for a song ever<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/chartbeat/502935/weekly-chart-notes-kelly-clarkson-adele-madonna|title=Weekly Chart Notes: Kelly Clarkson, Adele, Madonna|work=Billboard|accessdate=March 12, 2015}}</ref> "Hung Up" became the most successful dance song of the [[2000s in music|2000s]] in the United States, by topping the Dance/Club Play Songs Decade-end tally and "Music" became the second most-successful dance song of decade, reaching number two on the record chart.<ref name="dance decade">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts-decade-end/dance-club-play-songs?year=2009|title=Billboard Charts – Decade-end Singles – Dance/Club Play Songs|work=Billboard|accessdate=March 12, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108112432/http://www.billboard.com/charts-decade-end/dance-club-play-songs?year=2009|archivedate=November 8, 2012}}</ref> Furthermore, "Music" was also the longest-running number one song on Dance/Club Play Songs in the 2000s, with a longevity of five weeks at number one.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2000-09-16/dance-club-play-songs|title=Dance Club Play Songs|date=September 16, 2000|accessdate=March 12, 2015|publisher=''Billboard''. Nielsen Business Media, Inc.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2000-10-14/dance-club-play-songs|title=Dance Club Play Songs|date=October 14, 2000|accessdate=March 12, 2015|publisher=''Billboard''. Nielsen Business Media, Inc.}}</ref>

==== ''Billboard'' 200 chart statistics ==== {{see also|List of Billboard 200 number-one albums}} {{Pie chart | thumb = right | caption = Madonna's number-one albums on the ''Billboard'' 200 | other = | label1 =1980s: 3 albums | value1 =37.5 | label2 =1990s: 0 album | value2 =0 | label3 =2000s: 4 albums | value3 =50 | label4 =2010s: 1 album | value4 =12.5 }}
She is the second female artist with most number ones albums, with 8, behind only [[Barbra Streisand]], who has 10 number one albums.<ref name="StreisandRecord">{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/music/bp/chart-watch-barbras-six-decade-streak-at-1-221212338.html|title=Chart Watch: Barbra's Six-Decade Streak At #1|author=Paul Grein|publisher=Yahoo!|date=September 18, 2014|accessdate=March 9, 2015}}</ref> Her [[Billboard 200#Artist milestones|other achievements]] on the record chart, tied with [[Beyoncé]] as the female artist with most consecutive number-one albums.<ref name="Beyonce">{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1719282/beyonce-album-number-one-debut/|title=Beyoncé Debuts At #1, Makes Billboard History|author=James Montgomery|publisher=[[MTV]]|date=December 18, 2013|accessdate=March 9, 2015}}</ref> Also, in 1984 Madonna was the first female to sell over 5 million albums in the US in a single year with ''[[Like a Virgin (album)|Like a Virgin]]''.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Grein|first=Paul|date=August 10, 1985|title=Hot Madonna: July Fills Her Coffers With RIAA Metal|journal=Billboard|location=New York|volume=97|issue=32|pages=7|issn=0006-2510|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6iQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA7|accessdate=February 16, 2010}}</ref> Madonna is the artist with most top 10 albums on the Billboard 200, with 21 (20 in 2012, with ''MDNA'')<ref name="ElvisandMadonna"/> [[George Strait]] places second with 17 top 10s, followed by Mariah Carey (16). Also, she is the female artist with most number-two albums on Billboard's Top 200 Albums, with six, tied with The Beatles and behind [[Frank Sinatra]]'s seven
Her albums ''The Immaculate Collection'', ''Like a Virgin'' and ''True Blue'' are among the top 100 certified albums according to the [[RIAA]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinum.php?content_selector=top-100-albums|title=RIAA: Top 100 Certified Albums|publisher=Recording Industry Association of America|accessdate=August 6, 2012}}</ref> with ''The Immaculate Collection'' and ''Like a Virgin'' becoming in one of the [[List of best-selling albums in the United States|best-selling albums in United States]] with a [[RIAA certification|diamond status]]. As of 2015, she is the eighth artist with most number-one albums. However, she has a record for the biggest second week sales drop in history in [[Nielsen SoundScan]] era with her twelfth studio album, ''MDNA''.

==== Canadian singles chart statistics ==== {{see also|List of artists who reached number one on the Canadian Hot 100|List of number-one singles in Canada}} She has a total of 25 #1 singles in Canada — the most for any artist in spanning four decades: 1980s, 1990s, 2000s and 2010s. Only two of these number one singles belong to [[Canadian Hot 100]] and the rest of [[RPM (magazine)|Canadian RPM singles chart]]. Her 2000 single "Music" was [[List of number-one singles of 2000 (Canada)|the last number one hit]] on the [[RPM (magazine)|Canadian RPM singles chart]]. Also, she has sixty-eight Top 40, fifty-nine Top 20, fifty-one Top 10 and thirty-nine Top 5 singles.<ref name="canadiancharts"> For peak chart positions for Madonna's singles on Canadian charts from 2000–present, see [[AllMusic]] and the Billboard.com link. For Peak chart positions for Madonna's singles from 1983 to 1999, on Canada's ''RPM'' Singles Chart, see the RPM link. *{{cite web|url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-110.01-e.php?PHPSESSID=v2a76h62to0aart05gg0u3agj2&q1=Madonna|title=Madonna Singles Discography|work=[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]|publisher=RPM Library Archives|accessdate=April 3, 2015}} *{{cite web|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=madonna|chart=Billboard Canadian Hot 100}}|title=Madonna Album & Song Chart History – Billboard Canadian Hot 100|work=Billboard}} </ref> "4 Minutes" debuted at the top of the Canadian [[Contemporary Hit Radio]] chart. This marked the first time any song entered at the top of the CHR chart in [[Nielsen Broadcast Data Systems|BDS]] history.<ref name="canadian4minutes">{{cite press release|url=http://www.marketwire.com/press-release/madonna-4-minute-fever-spreads-across-the-world-victims-cant-stop-dancing-839706.htm|title='4 Minutes' is the fastest single to hit #1 in Canadian radio history|author=Press Release|date=March 26, 2008|publisher=[[Nielsen Broadcast Data Systems]]|page=2|accessdate=April 7, 2015}}</ref> With "Music and "American Pie" was the first time in Canadian chart history that an artist held the top two positions on the year-end musical charts.

==== Canadian albums chart statistics ==== {{see also|List of certified albums in Canada}} She has to date, two album with [[List of diamond-certified albums in Canada|diamond status in Canada]] with ''True Blue'' (in June 1987) and ''[[Like a Virgin (album)|Like a Virgin]]'' (July 1992). ==== UK Singles Chart statistics ==== {{see also|List of artists by number of UK Singles Chart number ones|List of UK Singles Chart number ones of the 1990s}}
Madonna has 13 number one hits in United Kingdom, a record for a female recording artist, spanning her number one for three decades: 1980s, 1990s and 2000s
In 1985, Madonna became the first female artist in UK chart history to hold the top-two positions of the chart simultaneously, with "[[Into the Groove]]" topping number one and "Holiday" the second place<ref name="mcaleer">{{harvnb|McAleer|2004|p=262}}</ref> By the end of 1985, Madonna achieved up another record with the song, becoming the first female artist to have eight UK top-ten singles in one calendar year.<ref>{{harvnb|Tobler|1991|p=198}}</ref> In 1987 when she published "La Isla Bonita", she became the female artist with the most number-one singles in the British chart history<ref>{{harvnb|Lazell|1989|p=311}}</ref>—a record that has since been maintained by Madonna to date<ref name="UKSInglesOne"/> Every single reached the UK Top 20 until 2008's "[[Miles Away (Madonna song)|Miles Away]]". Also, Madonna simultaneously topped the albums and singles charts 4 times in her career, which is unmatched by any other female artist. In 2014, [[Official Charts Company]] compiled her Top 40 biggest selling singles, with "[[Into the Groove]]" in the top with 870,000 copies.<ref name="Biggest40UK">{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/madonna-s-official-number-one-singles-sales-revealed-__3750/|title=Madonna's Official Number One Singles' Sales Revealed!|date=February 7, 2014|accessdate=April 2, 2015|publisher=Official Charts|author=Justin Myers}}</ref> Furthermore, Madonna had 71st Top 40 U.K. singles, the most for any female artist.<ref name="UKRecord"/> Her others milestones including, eleven Top 2 singles, sixty Top 10 and forty four Top 20 singles.

==== UK Albums Chart statistics ==== {{see also|List of artists by number of UK Albums Chart number ones|List of UK Albums Chart number ones of the 1990s|List of Platinum singles in the United Kingdom awarded since 2000|List of best-selling albums by year in the United Kingdom}}
She has 12 number-one albums with 9 studio albums —the most for any solo artist. Also, she has five number-two albums and twenty Top 5 albums, more than any other female artist. In 1986, ''True Blue'' opened at the top of the [[UK Albums Chart]] on July 12, 1986, making it the first album by American artist to debut at number one in British chart history.<ref name="ukalbum">{{cite web|url=http://www.theofficialcharts.com/archive-chart/_/3/1986-07-12/|title=UK Albums Chart – Week of July 12, 1986|date=July 12, 1986|accessdate=April 6, 2015|publisher=[[The Official Charts Company]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68ibwVIml?url=http://www.officialcharts.com/archive-chart/_/3/1986-07-12/|archivedate=June 26, 2012|df=}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Frith|Straw|Street|2001|p=16}}</ref> In 2012, with ''MDNA'' she became the first female in have an album in the number one during the 1980, 1990, 2000 and 2010.<ref name="MDNAfourdecades">{{cite web|title=Madonna y MDNA remueven los libros de récords musicales, ¡para siempre!|date=March 28, 2012|publisher=Impre.com}}</ref> Also, Madonna and [[Kylie Minogue]] are the only artists ever to have a number-one album and a number-one single in three different decades.
According to ''[[New Musical Express]]'' her albums ''The Immaculate Collection'' and ''Confessions on a Dance Floor'' are one of the 50 fastest selling albums ever in United Kingdom, selling 340,000 and 217,610 respectively. Making in the female artist with most entries.<ref name="fastalbum">{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/photos/50-fastest-selling-albums-ever/213617#/photo/1|title=50 fastest selling albums ever|accessdate=March 4, 2015|work=[[NME]]}}</ref> Both [[Michael Jackson]], Madonna had two of the [[List of best-selling albums of the 1980s in the United Kingdom|best selling albums of the decade 1980]] with ''True Blue'' (#9) and ''Like a Virgin'' (#17). Also during the 2000s, she figured [[List of best-selling albums of the 2000s (decade) in the United Kingdom|with two albums]] in the top 100 with ''Music'' and ''Confessions on a Dance Floor'' and she topped the [[List of UK Albums Chart Christmas number ones|UK chart Christmas]] with ''The Immaculate Collection'', making the first to the decade 1990s and occupied the record number one during nine weeks.

This is a list of some [[long-distance footpath]]s used for [[walking]] and [[hiking]].
==Africa==
===Namibia=== *[[Fish River Canyon]]
===South Africa=== *[[Otter Trail]] *[[Grand Traverse (South Africa)|Grand Traverse]], a 204 Kilometre (127 mi) walk in the [[Drakensberg]]
===Egypt=== *[[Sinai Trail]], a 250km thru-hike in Sinai from Nuweiba to St. Catherine mountain (Egypt highest summit)<ref>http://www.sinaitrail.org</ref>
==Asia==
===Bhutan=== *328 kilometers (216 mi) [[Snowman Trek]], a 21-day hike through the [[Himalayas]] [https://web.archive.org/web/20130502110011/http://www.nationalgeographic.com/adventure/adventure-travel/asia/bhutan-kira-salak.html]
====Hong Kong==== The merit of hiking trails in Hong Kong is that hikers can enjoy scenery of both the sea and highland. *[[Hong Kong Trail]]: across [[Hong Kong Island]] ({{convert|50|km}}) *[[Lantau Trail]]: on [[Lantau Island]] ({{convert|70|km}}) *[[Wilson Trail]]: from [[Stanley, Hong Kong|Stanley]], [[Hong Kong Island]] to [[Nam Chung]], [[New Territories]] ({{convert|78|km}}) *[[MacLehose Trail]]: from [[Sai Kung]] to [[Tuen Mun]] ({{convert|100|km}})
===Georgia===
Transcaucasian Trail:
A long distance trail in the caucasus has been a lingering idea for trekkers and hikers for many years since they started hiking remote parts of the Caucasus. Many sections of the TCT already exist, used by local community members and shepherds for centuries. These trail cross long valleys and traverse mammoth mountains to connect mountain villages together. Unfortunately, in recent years many of these trails have fallen into disrepair, and while many trails are known to locals, they are difficult to navigate for visitors and tourists. In 2015, two Peace Corps volunteers, Paul Stephens and Jeff Haack, mapped and charted known routes in The Republic of Georgia. During this time they succeeded in locating many connections between known trails and publicizing the concept of the trail. In 2016, Tom Allen and Alessandro Mambelli scouted new trail routes in Armenia while the first trail building project began in Svaneti, Georgia. In 2017, the trail building expanded to Dilijan National Park in Armenia while trail building continued in the Svaneti region. Today, over 300 km of trail has been improved and marked in Georgia and Armenia. Many 7-10 day guided hikes are available on the TCT this summer. Over the next 5 years, the trail will be expanded to connect all of the sections and create even longer hikes. The TCT can serve many purposes in the Caucasus region. For one, the natural diversity of the area needs to be protected. This habitat fosters many species of animal and provides unique ecosystems created by the mountains. More information about the trail can be found at transcaucasiantrail.org . Donations can be sustaining or one-time.
===Israel=== *[[Israel National Trail]]: {{convert|1000|km}}, all of them inside the [[Green Line (Israel)|Green Line]], from kibbutz [[Dan (kibbutz)|Dan]] to [[Eilat]] (north to south), covering many historic and scenic points including some urban areas. *[[Jerusalem Trail]]: {{convert|40|km|adj=on}} trail, connects the Israel National Trail with Jerusalem and the area of the old city. *[[Jesus Trail]]: {{convert|65|km}} in the Galilee region, connecting important sites from the life of Jesus. The trail begins in [[Nazareth]] and passes through [[Sepphoris]], [[Cana]], the horns of [[Hattin]], [[Arbel]] Cliffs, [[Capernaum]], [[Tabgha]], the [[Mount of Beatitudes]], the [[Jordan River]], and [[Mount Tabor]]. *[[Golan Trail]]: {{convert|130|km}} from Mt. Hermon (1500m) to the sea of Galilee (-200m) *[[Sea to sea trail]]: {{convert|70|km}} from the [[sea of Galilee]] to the [[Mediterranean Sea]] *[[Valley of the springs TRail]] (Emek HaMaayanot). A trek of about 140 km, around the Valley of springs near the See of Galilee. *[[Haifa Wadis Trail]]: {{convert|50|km|adj=on}} trail, connecting the Israel National Trail with Haifa and its surroundings.
===Japan=== *[[Hokkaidō Nature Trail]]: {{convert|4585|km}} all over the island of Hokkaidō(planning) *[[Tōhoku Nature Trail]]: {{convert|4374|km}} within prefectures of Aomori, Iwate, Miyagi, Akita, Yamagata and Fukushima *[[Chubu Hokuriku Nature Trail]]: {{convert|4029|km}} within prefectures of Gunma, Niigata, Toyama, Ishikawa, Fukui, Nagano, Gifu and Shiga *[[Kantō Fureai Trail]]: {{convert|1665|km}} within prefectures of Ibaraki, Tochigi, Gunma, Saitama, Chiba, Tōkyō and Kanagawa. Also known as the Capital Region Nature Trail.<ref>http://ja.japantourist.jp/view/the-kanto-fureai-no-michi-in-tokyo</ref> *[[Tōkaidō Nature Trail]]: {{convert|1697|km}} from Tokyo to Osaka via prefectures of Kanagawa, Yamanashi, Shizuoka, Aichi, Shiga, Gifu, Mie, Kyōto and Nara *[[Kinki Nature Trail]]: {{convert|3291|km}} within prefectures of Fukui, Mie, Shiga, Kyōto, Osaka, Hyōgo, Nara, Wakayama and Tottori *[[Chugoku Nature Trail]]: {{convert|2211|km}} within prefectures of Tottori, Shimane, Okayama, Hiroshima and Yamaguchi *[[Shikoku Nature Trail]]: {{convert|1637|km}} within prefectures of Ehime, Tokushima, Kagawa and Kōchi *[[Kyushu Nature Trail]]: {{convert|2587|km}} within prefectures of Fukuoka, Saga, Nagasaki, Kumamoto, Oita, Miyazaki and Kagoshima
===Jordan=== *600 kilometers (372 mi) [[Jordan Trail]]: north-south, cross country from Um Qais to Aqaba<ref>Route descriptions, maps, photos, etc. at [http://www.jordantrail.org/ jordantrail.org]</ref>
===Lebanon=== *[[Lebanon Mountain Trail]], a 26-day {{convert|440|km|adj=on}} trail through [[Mount Lebanon]]
===Malaysia=== *[[Grand Malaysia Trail]] (Kai Pengembara Negara-Kai Trails Around Malaysia): nationwide trail of more than {{convert|3000|km}} length
===Myanmar=== [[Hkakabo Razi]] Trail, climbing the highest peak in Myanmar, in [[Khakaborazi National Park]], and various footpaths in [[Putao]]
===Nepal=== *{{convert|4500|km}} [[The Great Himalaya Trail]] (GHT) is proposed to follow the Greater Himalaya Range from Namche Barwa in [[Tibet]] to Nanga Parbat in [[Pakistan]] forming the world's highest mountain trail. It will connect five Asian countries: [[Bhutan]], [[China]], [[India]], [[Nepal]], and Pakistan. It uses existing trails, many of which are trekking, trade, or pilgrimage routes, but no new trails have been built. Starting near [[Kangchenjunga|Kanchenjunga]] in the east and ending in [[Humla District|Humla]] in the west, the Nepal section has been walked and documented and is about {{convert|1600|km}}. (See the [http://www.thegreathimalayatrail.org/ Great Himalaya Trail website] and the [http://www.greathimalayatrail.com/ Great Himalaya Trail book website].) *Trek to [[Everest Base Camp]], an 18-day trail to the base camp of Mt. Everest (see [http://www.expeditionnepal.com/en/nepal/trekking/everest-base-camp-trek Everest Base Camp Trek at WikiVoyage]|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}) *230 kilometers (145 mi) [[Annapurna Circuit]], a 3-week loop trek through the [[Annapurna]] range (see [https://www.himalayastrek.com/annapurna-circuit-trekking/ Annapurna Circuit at WikiVoyage]) *277 kilometers (173 mi) [[Manaslu Circuit]], a 3-week loop trek through the adjacent range to the [[Annapurna]] region—the [[Manaslu]] region.
===Russia=== *[[Great Baikal Trail]] *[[Frolikha Adventure Coastline Track]] F.A.C.T.: {{convert|100|km}} trail at the northern tip of [[Lake Baikal]]
===South Korea=== * The [[Baekdudaegan]] Trail: {{convert|750|km}} along the ridge of the Baekdu Daegan mountain range, Korea's watershed divide. * [[Olle road|The Jeju Olle]] (400 km) is a series of connected walking courses that circumnavigate the coastline of Jeju Island.
===Turkey=== *[[Sufi Trail]] - 801 km trail from [[Istanbul]] to [[Konya]], following the Ottoman Sultans [[Hajj]] route *[[Lycian Way]] - 540 km trail around the south coast of Turkey *[[Saint Paul Trail]] - 500 km trail following [[Paul the Apostle|St Paul]]'s 1st journey *[http://www.sultanstrail.com Sultans Trail] - from Vienna to İstanbul, following the Ottoman Sultans *[http://cultureroutesinturkey.com/c/hittite-trail/ Hittite Trail - in central Turkey on ancient Hittite roads] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20140924050937/http://cultureroutesinturkey.com/c/kackar-mountains-trails/ Kackar Trails - 8 multi-day trails in Northeast Turkey] *[[Evliya Çelebi Way]] - the first part of [[Evliya Çelebi|Evliya]]'s route to Mecca in the 17th century *[http://cultureroutesinturkey.com/c/phrygian-way/ Phrygian Way - 600km route around the Phrygian Valleys near Ankara] *[http://www.cariantrail.com Carian Trail - 800km trail around the south-west coast of Turkey] *[http://www.abrahampath.org Abraham Path - international route starting in Urfa, southeast Turkey] *[http://www.trekkinginturkey.com Trekking in Turkey - website of Turkish trekking routes] *[http://www.trekkingararat.com Trekking Ararat - Trekking guide service in Turkey] *[http://trekopedia.com/?page_id=471 Trekopedia - Trail reference database that covers the Lycian Way]
==Europe== *The [[GR footpath]]s in [[Belgium]], [[France]], [[Spain]] and the [[Netherlands]] *[[European long-distance paths]], over 70.000 km of 12 long-distance E-paths. *The [[Tour du Mont Blanc]] circles the Mont Blanc Massif covering a distance of roughly 170 kilometres (110 mi) with 10 kilometres (6.2 mi) of ascent/descent and passes through parts of Switzerland, Italy and France *The ''[[Haute Randonnée Pyrénéenne]]'' (HRP) in the [[Pyrenees]] in France, Spain and [[Andorra]] *{{convert|800|km}} [[Nordkalottleden Trail]] (Kalottireitti) in the northernmost parts of [[Finland]], [[Sweden]], and [[Norway]] ([[Sápmi (area)|Lapland]]) *{{convert|2530|km}} Camino de Santiago de Compostela, or [[St James's Way]], commonly walked through France and Spain, but including old pilgrimage [[Way of St. James (route descriptions)|routes]] from as far afield as [[Poland]] and [[Portugal]], and adding as many as {{convert|1906|km}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20061211032003/http://www.peterrobins.co.uk/camino/] *''Peaks of the Balkans Trail'', through [[Montenegro]], [[Albania]] and [[Kosovo]] *{{convert|2200|km}} [[Sultans Trail]] in [[Austria]], [[Slovakia]], [[Hungary]], [[Croatia]], [[Serbia]], [[Romania]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Greece]], and [[Turkey]] *{{convert|5000|km}} The [[Via Alpina]] network of Alpine trails **{{convert|1500|km}} Red Trail [http://www.backpackinglight.com/cgi-bin/backpackinglight/via_alpina_not_another_walk_in_the_woods.html#.UXcTvoVBEy5] **Violet Trail **Yellow Trail **Green Trail **Blue Trail *[[Via Francigena]] from Canterbury to Rome * [[:it:Tratturo L'Aquila-Foggia]] from L'Aquila (Abruzzo region, Italy) to Foggia (Puglia region, Italy). At 244 km, Tratturo Magno is the longest and the most important ancient route, traversed by shepherds in [[Transhumance]]
===Austria=== *[[Arnoweg]] around the Austrian Alps *[[Alpe Adria Trail]], Austria, Slovenia, Italy *[[North Alpine Trail]] *[[Central Alpine Trail]] *[[South Alpine Trail]] *[[North South Path]] *[[East Austrian Borderland Trail]] *[[Sultans Trail]] Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, Romania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey *[[Way of the book]]
===Bulgaria=== *[[Kom-Emine]] {{convert|700|km}}, from Mount Kom to [[Cape Emine]] (part of [[European walking route E3]])<ref>[http://www.walkingworld.co.uk/home/index.asp?id=32&nid=183 KOM-EMINE] from Walkingworld</ref> *[[Sultans Trail]] Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, Romania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey
===Croatia=== *[[Sultans Trail]] Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, Romania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey
===Czechia=== *[[Polish - Czech Friendship Trail]]: trail along the Polish and Czech border in [[Sudetes]]
===Denmark=== *[[Hærvejen]], ancient trail on the [[Jutland Peninsula]]. *[[Øhavsstien]] 220 km around the archipelago of southern Denmark [[Fünen]]. *[[Gendarmstien]], 74 km following the border between Germany and Denmark. *[https://bornholmrundt.dk Bornholm Rundt]. A walk around of the island of [[Bornholm]] (120 km). *[http://camoenoen.dk Camønoen] A walk on the island of Møn (175 km).
=== Estonia === * [[Peraküla, Lääne County|Peraküla]]-[[Aegviidu]]-[[Ähijärve]], 820 kilometres from North-East to South-West Estonia<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://loodusegakoos.ee/where-to-go/hiking-route/perakula-aegviidu-ahijarve-hiking-route|title=Loodusega Koos|website=Loodusega Koos|access-date=2017-06-05}}</ref> * [[Oandu, Lääne-Viru County|Oandu]]-[[Aegviidu]]-[[Ikla]], 375 kilometres from North to South Estonia<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://loodusegakoos.ee/where-to-go/hiking-route/oandu-aegviidu-ikla-hiking-route|title=Loodusega Koos|website=Loodusega Koos|access-date=2017-06-05}}</ref>
===Finland=== *The [[Karhunkierros]] Trail ({{convert|80|km}}, [https://web.archive.org/web/20070310220324/http://www.luontoon.fi/page.asp?Section=7494 External link]) in the municipalities of [[Kuusamo]] and [[Salla]], Oulanka National Park, [[Lapland, Finland|Lapland]] *The Peuran polku Trail: ({{convert|115|km}}, [https://web.archive.org/web/20061007161511/http://www.luontoon.fi/page.asp?Section=5319 External link]) in the municipalities of Kivijärvi, Kinnula, Perho, Lestijärvi and Reisjärvi in [[Central Finland]], [[Central Ostrobothnia]], and [[Northern Ostrobothnia]]—a part of [[European walking route E6]]
===France=== * [[GR footpath#France: Grande Randonnée|Sentier de Grande Randonnée (GR)]] * [[Haute Randonnée Pyrénéenne]] (HRP): High Pyrenees Trail, along the border with Spain. * The [[Tour du Lot]]: a circuit of over {{convert|500|km}} around the Department of the Lot's periphery. * [[Metropolitan Trail|Sentier Métropolitain]]: urban and suburban hiking routes, that allow their users to discover a metropolitan territory in several days of hiking.
===Germany=== * Barbarossaweg: Korbach to Kyffhäuserdenkmal ({{convert|332|km}}) * Bergischer Weg: Essen to Königswinter ({{convert|137|km}}) * [[Birkenhainer Strasse]]: Hanau to Gemünden am Main ({{convert|71|km}}) * Bonifatiusweg: Mainz to Fulda ({{convert|180|km}}) * Christine-Koch-Weg: Menden to Bad Laasphe ({{convert|123|km}}) * [[Eselsweg]]: Schlüchtern to Großheubach ({{convert|111|km}}) *[[König-Ludwig-Weg]]: Berg am Starnberger See to Füssen ({{convert|120|km}}) *[[Maximiliansweg]]: Lindau to Berchtesgaden ({{convert|350|km}}) *[[Moselhöhenweg]]: Trier to Koblenz *[[Pandurensteig]]: Waldmuenchen to Passau *[[Rennsteig]]: Hörsel to Blankenstein/Saale through the Thuringian Forest ({{convert|169|km}}) *[[Rheinburgenweg Trail]]: Bingen to Koblenz to Rüdesheim am Rhein (''c''.{{convert|200|km}}) *[[Rheinhöhenweg Trail]]: Bonn to Alsheim/Wiesbaden ({{convert|530|km}}) *[[Rheinsteig]]: Bonn to Wiesbaden ({{convert|320|km}}) *[[Westweg]] (Black Forest western ridgeway): Pforzheim to Basel ({{convert|279|km}}) *[[Mittelweg]] (Black Forest central ridgeway): Pforzheim to Waldshut ({{convert|233|km}}) *[[Ostweg]] (Black Forest eastern ridgeway): Pforzheim to Schaffhausen ({{convert|238|km}}) *[[Black Forest North Perimeter Way]]: Mühlacker to Karlsruhe ({{convert|71|km}}) * [[Freiburg-Lake Constance Black Forest Trail]]: Freiburg to Konstanz ({{convert|183|km}}) *[[Saar-Hunsrück-Steig]]: Trier to Saarschleife in Mettlach or Idar-Oberstein 9 ({{convert|180|km}})
===Greece=== *[[European walking route E4]] ([[Florina]] to [[Agios Nikolaos, Crete|Agios Nikolaos]]) *[[European walking route E6]] ([[Igoumenitsa]] to [[Alexandroupoli]]) *[[Sultans Trail]] Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, Romania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey
===Hungary=== *[[Countrywide Blue Tour in Hungary]] (part of European long-distance footpath [[European walking route E4|E4]]) *[[Sultans Trail]] Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, Romania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey
===Iceland=== *[[Laugavegur]] from Landmannalaugar to Thorsmork to Skógar ({{convert|80|km}})
===Italy=== *[[Grand Italian Trail]] (Sentiero Italia): nationwide trail of more than {{convert|6000|km}} length *[[Via Francigena]]: pilgrimage route across Italy to Rome from France *[[Emilia-Romagna]]: [[:it:Via_degli_Dei|Via degli Dei]] is a path (135km, 80mi) that crosses the Apennines from [[Bologna]] to [[Florence]]. * Dolomites: **[http://digilander.libero.it/a1bftx/AltaVia1/html/indexe.htm Dolomites Classical High Route (no.1) from Braies Lake to Belluno] **[http://digilander.libero.it/a2bftx/AltaVia2/html/indexe.htm High Route of the Legends (no.2) from Brixen to Feltre] **[http://www.dolomiti.it/eng/itinerari/altevie/altavia3.htm Dolomites High Route of the Chamoi (no.3) from Villabassa to Longarone] **[https://web.archive.org/web/20110722040430/http://www.infodolomiti.it/dolomiti.run?3B024380-1 Dolomites Grohmann's High Route (no.4) from San Candido in Pusteria to Pieve di Cadore] **[http://www.dolomiti.it/eng/itinerari/altevie/altavia5.htm Dolomites Titans's High Route (no.5) from Sesto in Pusteria to Pieve di Cadore] **[http://www.dolomiti.it/eng/itinerari/altevie/altavia6.htm Dolomites High Route of Silence (no.6) from Pieve d'Alpago to Vittorio Veneto] **[http://www.dolomiti.it/eng/itinerari/altevie/altavia7.htm Dolomites Patera's High Route (no.7) from Ponte nelle Alpi to Tambre d'Alpago] **[http://www.dolomiti.it/eng/itinerari/altevie/altavia8.htm Dolomites High Route of the Heroes (no.8) from Feltre to Bassano del Grappa] **[http://www.dolomiti.it/eng/itinerari/altevie/altavia9.htm Dolomites High Route (n. 9): the Trasversale from Bolzano to Santo Stefano di Cadore] **[http://www.dolomiti.it/eng/itinerari/altevie/altavia10.htm Dolomites High Route (n. 10) of Giudicarie from Bolzano to the Garda Lake] * [[Liguria]]: **[http://digilander.iol.it/lgbftaaaa/5terre/html/indexe.htm Liguria: From Portovenere to Camogli] hiking trail along the sea **[[Alta Via dei Monti Liguri]] **Sentiero Azzurro is a trail along a rugged portion of coast on the [[Italian Riviera]] that connects the five towns known as the [[Cinque Terre]] in Liguria, Italy * [[Lombardy]] **[http://digilander.iol.it/viabftx/viandante/html/indexe.htm ''Il Sentiero del Viandante''] The "Wayfarer's trail" from [[Lecco]] to [[Colico]] on the east side of [[Lake Como]]. **[http://www.lakecomo.it/en/excursions_and_trekking/il_sentiero_delle_4_valli ''Il Sentiero delle 4 Valli''] The "Four Valleys Path" between Lake Como and [[Lake Lugano]] **''[[La Via dei Monti Lariani]]'': The Monti Lariani trail on the west side of Lake Como, from [[Cernobbio]] to [[Sorico]] * [[Piedmont]] **[[Grande Traversata delle Alpi]] (GTA): 55 days in the Alps of Piedmont * [[Tuscany]] ** ''Grande Escursione Appenninica'' (Great Apennines Walk): largely along the ridge of the [[Apennine Mountains]]
===Montenegro=== *Primorska planinarska transverzala (Coastal Mountain Transversal), from [[Herceg Novi]] to [[Bar]], 180km *Crnogorska Transverzala (Montenegrin Transversal), from [[Durmitor]] to [[Kučka Krajina]], 140km
===Netherlands=== *[[Zevenwoudenpad]] from Lauwersoog to Steenwijk ({{convert|200|km}}) *[[Pionierspad]] from Steenwijk to Muiden ({{convert|200|km}}) *[[Floris V-pad]] from Amsterdam to Bergen op Zoom ({{convert|245|km}}) *[[Trekvogelpad]] from Bergen aan Zee to Enschede ({{convert|380|km}}) *[[Marskramerpad]] from Bad Bentheim to Den Haag ({{convert|360|km}}) *[[Maarten van Rossumpad]] from 's-Hertogenbosch to Ommen ({{convert|308|km}}) *[[Deltapad]] from Sluis to Hoek van Holland ({{convert|237|km}}) *[[Hollands Kustpad]] from Hoek van Holland to Den Helder ({{convert|213|km}}) *[[Friese Kustpad]] from Stavoren to Lauwersoog ({{convert|131|km}}) *[[Wad- en Wierdenpad]] from Lauwersoog to Nieuweschans ({{convert|123|km}}) *[[Oeverloperpad]] from Rotterdam Europoort to Leerdam ({{convert|232|km}}) *[[Lingepad]] from Leerdam to Nijmegen (German border) ({{convert|98|km}}) *[[Pelgrimspad]] from Amsterdam to Maastricht ({{convert|453|km}}) *[[Zuiderzeepad]] from Enkhuizen to Stavoren ({{convert|400|km}}) *[[Pieterpad]] from Pieterburen to the Sint Pietersberg ({{convert|492|km}}) *[[Noaberpad]] from Nieuweschans to Emmerich ({{convert|363|km}}) *[[Grenslandpad]] from Sluis to Thorn ({{convert|363|km}}) *[[Overijssels Havezatenpad]] from Oldenzaal to Steenwijk ({{convert|272|km}}) *[[Peellandpad]] from 's-Hertogenbosch to Roermond ({{convert|160|km}}) * [[Airbornepad]] from the Belgian border to Arnhem
===Norway=== *[[Jotunheimen Trail]] (Norwegian: "Jotunheimstien"): {{convert|320|km}} from downtown Oslo to Lake Gjende in Jotunheimen *[[Nordkalottruta]] (Finnish: Kalottireitti, Swedish: Nordkalottleden): {{convert|800|km}} from Kautokeino (located in Finnmark, Northern Norway) to Sulitjelma (Norway) or alternately Kvikkjokk (Sweden)
=== Poland === *[[Główny Szlak Sudecki]] (Main Sudety Trail): {{convert|440|km}} in [[Sudetes]] Mountains from [[Świeradów Zdrój]] to [[Prudnik]] *[[Main Beskid Trail|Główny Szlak Beskidzki]] (Main Beskidy Trail): {{convert|519|km}} in [[Beskids]] Mountains, from [[Wołosate]] to [[Ustroń]],<ref>[http://www.czerwonyszlak.republika.pl/opis_trasy.htm Główny Szlak Beskidzki - opis trasy]</ref> the longest public trail in Poland *[[Polish - Czech Friendship Trail]]: trail along the Polish and Czech border in [[Sudetes]]
=== Portugal === * [[Rota Vicentina]]
===Romania=== *[[Sultans Trail]] Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, Romania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey
===Republic of Ireland=== *[[Long-distance trails in the Republic of Ireland]]
===Serbia=== *[[Sultans Trail]] Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, Romania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey * The Fruška Gora Transversal (Serbian: ''Fruškogorska Transverzala'') - circular trail around [[Fruška gora|<nowiki/>]][[Fruška Gora]] mountain - 160 km (100 mi) * The Small Toplica Transversal (Serbian: ''Mala Toplička Transverzala'') - 122 km (76 mi)
===Slovakia=== *[[The Slovak National Uprising Heroes Trail]] {{convert|750|km}} from east to west (Dukla Bradlo) across mountainous regions of Slovakia *[[Sultans Trail]] Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, Romania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey
===Slovenia=== *[[Slovenian Mountain Hiking Trail]] {{convert|599|km}} from east ([[Maribor]]) to west ([[Ankaran]])
===Spain=== * [[Way of St. James]] (Spanish: El Camino de Santiago) * [[Route of the Monasteries of Valencia]] (Spanish: Ruta de los Monasterios de Valencia) * [[Grande Randonnée]] 7 ([[GR 7 (Spain)|GR 7]]): From [[Tarifa]] to the mountain cabin of Fontferrera, part of the [[European walking route E4|E4]] route. * [[Grande Randonnée]] 11 ([[GR 11 (Spain)|GR 11]]): [[Pyrenees]] Trail, staying within Spain. * [[Haute Randonnée Pyrénéenne]] (HRP): High Pyrenees Trail, along the border with France. * [http://www.caminodosfaros.com O Camiño dos Faros (The Lighthouse Way)] : 200 km (124 mi) along the coastline from Malpica to Fisterra, in Galicia (Spain)
===Sweden=== *[[Kungsleden]], {{convert|425|km}} from the northern extremity of the country *[http://www.sormlandsleden.se/default.aspx Sörmlandsleden] {{convert|1000|km}} of winding paths through the county of Sörmland. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100920070341/http://www.nordwinde.de/InfoBohus_eng.html Bohusleden] {{convert|360|km}} past at Göteborg, Uddevalla, Munkedal and ends finally in Strömstad * [[Ingegerdsleden]], 110 kilometres (68 mi), pilgrimage route in county of [[Uppland]] between [[Uppsala Cathedral]] and [[Stockholm Cathedral]]. * [[Skåneleden]], more than {{convert|1000|km}} long path through the province of [[Scania]]. Part of the [[North Sea Trail]].
===Switzerland=== See: [[:Category:Hiking trails in Switzerland|Hiking trails in Switzerland]]
===United Kingdom=== *[[Long-distance footpaths in the United Kingdom]]
==North America==
===Canada=== *420 km (260 mi) long [[Alexander MacKenzie Heritage Trail]] (aka Blackwater Trail) in [[British Columbia]] *Almost 900 km (560 mi) long [[Bruce Trail]] in [[Ontario]] *33-mile (53 km) long [[Chilkoot Trail]] in British Columbia and [[Alaska|Alaska, USA]] *540 kilometres (340 mi) long [[East Coast Trail]] in [[Newfoundland]] *5,400 miles (8,700 km) long [[Eastern Continental Trail]] from Newfoundland to [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia, USA]] *1,200 km long (745 mi) [[Great Divide Trail]] in [[Alberta]] and British Columbia *3058 km (1900 mi) long [[International Appalachian Trail]] from Newfoundland to [[Maine|Maine, USA]] *47 km (29 mi) long [[Juan de Fuca Trail]] in British Columbia *63 km (39 mi) long [[Mantario Trail]] in [[Manitoba]] and Ontario *[[National Hiking Trail of Canada]] [http://www.nationaltrail.ca/] *387-kilometre (240 mi) long [[Rideau Trail]] in Ontario *[[Trans-Canada Trail]] 18,000 kilometres (11,000 mi) long as of February 2016 *600 km (373 mi) long [[Voyageur Hiking Trail]] in Ontario *75 km (47 mi) long [[West Coast Trail]] in British Columbia *78-kilometre (48 mi) long [[La Cloche Silhouette Trail]] in Ontario *41 kilometres (25 mi) long [[Fundy Footpath]] in [[New Brunswick]] *220-kilometre (140 mi) long [[Capital Pathway]] in Ontario and [[Quebec]] *[[Vancouver Island Spine Trail]] in British Columbia *180 km, Sunshine Coast Trail in British Columbia
===Greenland=== *~100 mi (165 km) [[:de:Arctic Circle Trail|Arctic Circle Trail]]
===Panama=== *700-mile [[TransPanama Trail]] [http://planet-wild.com/transpanama-hike-over-700-miles-of-hiking/]
===United States=== *[[Long-distance trails in the United States]]
==Oceania==
===Australia=== See: [[List of long-distance hiking tracks in Australia]]
===New Zealand=== *[[New Zealand tramping tracks]] *[http://www.teararoa.org.nz/index.cfm Te Araroa] {{convert|3000|km}} Stretching from Cape Reinga in the north of New Zealand to Bluff in the South.
==South America==
===Argentina=== *[[Los Glaciares]] ** Various options to Laguna Torre, Cerro FitzRoy, or even out onto the [[Southern Patagonian Ice Field]] *[[Huella Andina]] ** 570 kilometers from [[Alumine Lake]] to [[Baggilt lake]]<ref>http://huellaandina.desarrolloturistico.gov.ar/</ref>
===Bolivia=== *[[Cordillera Real (Bolivia)]] ** 106 kilometres (66 mi) 7-day Illampu Circuit
===Brazil=== *[[Serra dos Órgãos]] ** {{convert|36|km}} between Petrópolis and Teresópolis (medium to hard trail) *[[Transcarioca Trail]] ** {{convert|183|km}} in Rio de Janeiro city (medium to hard trail) <ref>http://trilhatranscarioca.com.br/</ref> *[[Transmantiqueira Trail]] ** {{convert|700|km}} between Extrema and Aiuruoca (very hard trail) <ref>https://www.facebook.com/trilhatransmantiqueira/</ref> *[[Caminho da Fe]] ** {{convert|538| km}}. There are 3 different starting points: *** from Sao Carlos to [[Aparecida]] *** or from Cravinhos to Aparecida *** or from Mococa to Aparecida
===Chile=== *Central Chile and Patagonia **3,000 kilometers (1,850 mi) [[Hiking in Chile#Greater Patagonian Trail|Greater Patagonian Trail]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Dudeck|first1=Jan|title=Greater Patagonian Trail|url=http://www.wikiexplora.com/index.php/Greater_Patagonian_Trail|website=wikiexplora|accessdate=17 August 2014}}</ref> from the capital Santiago de Chile to the Southern Patagonian Ice Field. *Magallanes **118 kilometers. Full circuit of [[Torres del Paine]], including Valle del Francés and access to the base of Torres del Paine.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Meneses|first1=Patricia|title=Trekking Torres del Paine|url=http://www.wikiexplora.com/index.php/Trekking_Torres_del_Paine|website=Wikiexplora|accessdate=17 August 2014}}</ref> **Dientes de Navarino Circuit ~53km. 3 - 7 days. Starts out of Puerto Williams. Access from mainland Chile by ferry from Punta Areas, plane or from Ushuaia. http://rutas.bienes.cl/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/01.pdf
===Peru=== *[[Cordillera Blanca]] and [[Huayhuash mountain range|Huayhuash]] mountain range near [[Huaráz]] **30 kilometers (19 mi) 10- to 14-day trek on the Huayhuash Circuit **52 kilometers (33 mi) 3- to 4-day "W" Circuit Santa Cruz trek **94 kilometers (59 mi) 6- to 10-day Alpamayo Circuit, full "O" Circuit *[[Sacred Valley]] & [[Vilcanota mountain range]] near [[Cuzco]] **88 kilometers (55 mi) for the longest Mollepata variant of the [[Inca trail]], with options for a single day to more than six days, all ending at [[Machu Picchu]] **32 kilometers (20 mi) Cachora to [[Choquequirao]] trek **80 kilometers (50 mi) 5- to 6-day trek on Ausangate Circuit *[[Colca Canyon]] near [[Arequipa]] **60 kilometers (37 mi) 5-day trek around Canyon or other single-day and multi-day hikes

__NOTOC__ [[File:Bahji.jpg|thumb|The final place of exile of Bahá'u'lláh: the Mansion at Bahjí, [[Acre, Israel]].]] [[File:Mansion of Bahji 2.jpg|thumb|Mansion of Bahjí]] [[File:PikiWiki Israel 14856 BAHAI garden ACCO.jpg|thumb|[[Bahá'í gardens]] at Bahjí]] The '''Mansion of Bahjí''' ({{lang-ar|قصر بهجي}}, Qasr Bahjī, ''mansion of delight'') is a summer house in [[Acre, Israel]] where [[Bahá'u'lláh]], the founder of the [[Bahá'í Faith]], died in 1892. [[Shrine of Bahá'u'lláh|His shrine]] is located next to this house. The whole area was called ''Al-Bahjá'' (''Place of Delight'').
The area was originally a garden planted by [[Sulayman Pasha al-Adil|Sulayman Pasha]], who was the ruler of Acre, for his daughter Fatimih, and he named it Bahji.<ref name="Balyuzi362">{{Harvnb|Balyuzi|2000|p=362}}</ref> Later the area was further beautified by `Abdu'llah Pasha, and in 1831 when [[Ibrahim Pasha of Egypt|Ibrahim Pasha]] besieged Acre he used the property as his headquarters.<ref name="Balyuzi362"/> The property was well known for its beautiful gardens and pond fed by an aqueduct. The property then fell into the possession of a Christian family, the Jamals.<ref name="Balyuzi362"/>
In 1870 `Udi Khammar, a wealthy merchant from Acre who also originally owned the [[Bahá'í World Centre buildings#House of `Abbúd|House of `Abbúd]], bought some of the land from the Jamals close to the mansion of `Abdu'llah Pasha and built the Mansion of Bahji, over an earlier and smaller building, which Abdu'llah Pasha had had built for his mother.<ref>{{cite book |last=Ruhe |first= David |editor1-last= |editor1-first= |date= 1983 |orig-year=| chapter= |title= Door of Hope: The Bahá'í Faith in the Holy Land |url= |location= Oxford, England |publisher= George Ronald Publisher Ltd |page= 106 |isbn = 978-0853981503 |author-link= David Ruhe}}</ref><ref name="Balyuzi362"/><ref name="PSmith">{{Harvnb|Smith|2000|pp=87–89}}</ref> `Udi Khammar had built the house for his family, and when he died was buried in a tomb in the south-east corner of the wall directly around the building.<ref name="Balyuzi362"/><ref name="Taherzadeh">{{Harvnb|Taherzadeh|1987|p=103}}</ref> In 1879 an epidemic caused the inhabitants to flee and the building became vacant.
[[`Abdu'l-Bahá]] first rented, and then purchased, the mansion for Bahá'u'lláh and the [[Bahá'í Faith|Bahá'í]] holy family to live in, and Bahá'u'lláh moved from [[Mazra'ih]] to Bahji and resided in the building until his death.<ref name="Balyuzi362"/><ref name="Taherzadeh"/> In 1890 the Cambridge orientalist [[Edward Granville Browne]] met Bahá'u'lláh in this house; after this meeting he wrote his famous [[Bahá'u'lláh#Bahj.C3.AD|pen-portrait of Bahá'u'lláh]].<ref name="PSmith"/>
When Bahá'u'lláh died in 1892 he was interred in one of the surrounding buildings, and that building became the [[shrine of Bahá'u'lláh]].<ref name="PSmith"/> After his death in 1898, Bahá'u'lláh's son [[Bahá'u'lláh's family#Díyá'u'lláh|Díyá'u'lláh]] was initially buried next to his father. However, having been declared a [[Covenant-breaker]], Díyá'u'lláh's remains were disinterred in a "process" of "purification" through "cleansing" the "inner sanctuary" of the "most hallowed shrine", the "[[Qiblih]]" of the "Bahá'í World".<ref>{{cite book |editor1-last= Marks |editor1-first= Geoffry W. |date=1996 |title=Messages from the Universal House of Justice 1963-86: The Third Epoch of the Formative Age |url= http://bahai-library.com/uhj_messages_1963-86_full&chapter=3#66 |location= |publisher= Baha'i Publishing Trust |page=66 |isbn= 978-0877432395}}</ref> The site has since been beautified with [[paradise garden]]s, which are termed ''Haram-i-Aqdas'' (the Most Holy Precincts or Sanctuary) and are intersected by a circular path which serves to [[Circumambulation|circumambulate]] the shrine of Bahá'u'lláh.<ref name="PSmith"/> The Mansion, shrine, and surrounding gardens are among the most sacred spots on earth for Bahá'ís and are [[Bahá'í pilgrimage]] sites.<ref name="Balyuzi362"/><ref name="PSmith"/>
On November 12, 1952, a cablegram sent by Shoghi Effendi announced the "acquisition of vitally-needed property" of the Mansion of Bahji and the area around it from "the [[Israel Land Authority| Development Authority of the State of Israel]]...The exchange of said property, including land and houses, was made possible by the [[1948 Palestinian exodus|precipitate flight of the former Arab owners]]."<ref>{{cite book |last= Effendi |first= Shoghi | authorlink= Shoghi Effendi |date= 1971 |title= Messages To The Bahá'í World: 1950-1957 |url= http://bahai-library.com/shoghieffendi_messages_bahai_world |location= Wilmette, Illinois |chapter-url= http://bahai-library.com/writings/shoghieffendi/mbw/sec-25.html |chapter= Acquisition of Vitally-Needed Property |publisher= Bahá'í Publishing Trust |page= 45 |isbn= 978-0877430360 }}</ref>

The '''[[rainbow]]''', a natural phenomenon noted for its design and its place in the sky, has been a favorite component of art and religion throughout history. ==Religious belief== [[File:WhereRainbowRises.jpg|thumb|upright|The proverbial "end" of a rainbow. An observer situated at that location would only see the rainbow end at a further distance.]] {{Main|Rainbows in mythology}} The rainbow has a place in legend owing to its beauty and the historical difficulty in explaining the phenomenon. In [[Greco-Roman mythology]], the rainbow was considered to be a path made by a messenger ([[Iris (mythology)|Iris]]) between Earth and Heaven. In [[Chinese mythology]], the rainbow was a slit in the sky sealed by goddess [[Nüwa]] using stones of five different colours. The Irish [[leprechaun]]'s secret hiding place for his pot of gold is usually said to be at the end of the rainbow. This place is impossible to reach, because the rainbow is an optical effect which depends on the location of the viewer. When walking towards the end of a rainbow, it will appear to "move" further away (two people who simultaneously observe a rainbow at different locations will disagree about where a rainbow is). According to Genesis, after Noah's flood God put the rainbow in the sky as the sign of His promise that He would never again destroy the earth with flood (Genesis 9:13–17):''[[King James Version|Holy Bible: (King James Version.)]]'' (2004). Intellectual Reserve, inc.
I do set my bow in the cloud, and it shall be for a token of a covenant between me and the earth. And it shall come to pass, when I bring a cloud over the earth, that the bow shall be seen in the cloud: And I will remember my covenant, which is between me and you and every living creature of all flesh; and the waters shall no more become a flood to destroy all flesh. And the bow shall be in the cloud; and I will look upon it, that I may remember the everlasting covenant between God and every living creature of all flesh that is upon the earth. And God said unto Noah, This is the token of the covenant, which I have established between me and all flesh that is upon the earth.
Rabbinic Judaism learns from this portion of the Bible that rainbows are a symbol of divine anger and patience. On the occasion of seeing a rainbow, a blessing is said, thanking God for promising to never again flood the world. As well, there were certain Rabbis who never had rainbows appear in their lifetimes, such as [[Simeon bar Yochai|Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai]] and [[Joshua ben Levi|Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi]]. The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints founder and prophet Joseph Smith stated that the second coming of the Christ would not occur in any year in which a rainbow is seen."I have asked of the Lord concerning His coming; and while asking the Lord, He gave a sign and said, "In the days of Noah I set a bow in the heavens as a sign and token that in any year that the bow should be seen the Lord would not come; but there should be seed time and harvest during that year: but whenever you see the bow withdrawn, it shall be a token that there shall be famine, pestilence, and great distress among the nations, and that the coming of the Messiah is not far distant." Teachings of the Prophet Joseph Smith, Section Six 1843-44, p.340 In the [[Dreamtime]] of [[Australian Aboriginal mythology]], the [[rainbow snake]] is the deity governing [[water]]. In [[Amazon Basin|Amazonian]] cultures, rainbows have long been associated with malign spirits that cause harm, such as miscarriages and (especially) skin problems. In the [[Yanesha' language|Amuesha]] language of central [[Peru]], certain diseases are called ''ayona’achartan'', meaning "the rainbow hurt my skin". A tradition of closing one's mouth at the sight of a rainbow in order to avoid disease appears to pre-date the Incan empire.{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/j.jep.2009.09.024|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6T8D-4XFPR09-1&_user=9544096&_coverDate=01%2F08%2F2010&_rdoc=1&_fmt=high&_orig=search&_origin=search&_sort=d&_docanchor=&view=c&_searchStrId=1448860523&_rerunOrigin=google&_acct=C000039618&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=9544096&md5=55d589e8367329b7e92f31a06e4c7021&searchtype=a |title=The rainbow hurts my skin: Medicinal concepts and plants uses among the Yanesha (Amuesha), an Amazonian Peruvian ethnic group|author1=Céline Valadeau |author2=Joaquina Alban Castillo |author3=Michel Sauvain |author4=Augusto Francis Lorese |author5=Geneviève Bourdy |journal= Journal of Ethnopharmacology| volume =127| issue= 1|date= January 8, 2010| pages= 175–192|pmid=19835943}}{{cite web | url= http://www.amazonpromise.org/index.php?pagename=trad_med |title=Utilizing Western and Traditional Remedies in the Peruvian Amazon|author= Webster, Patty}} In [[New Age]] and [[Hindu philosophy]], the seven colours of the rainbow represent the seven [[chakra]]s, from the first chakra (red) to the seventh chakra (violet). ==Art== Rainbows are generally described as very colourful and peaceful. The rainbow occurs often in paintings.Niels Hutchison. "Stairways to Heaven". Colour Music. http://www.colourmusic.info/rain.htm/ Frequently these have a symbolic or programmatic significance (for example, [[Albrecht Dürer]]'s [[Melancholia I]]). In particular, the rainbow appears regularly in religious art (for example, [[Joseph Anton Koch]]'s ''Noah's Thank Offering''). Romantic landscape painters such as [[J. M. W. Turner|Turner]] and [[John Constable|Constable]] were more concerned with recording fleeting effects of light (for example, Constable's [[Salisbury Cathedral from the Meadows]]). Other notable examples appear in work by [[Hans Memling]], [[Caspar David Friedrich]], and [[Peter Paul Rubens]]. {| style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;" |[[File:Millais-Blind Girl.jpg|thumb|150px|''The Blind Girl'', oil painting (1856) by [[John Everett Millais]]. The rainbow – one of the beauties of nature that the blind girl cannot experience – is used to underline the pathos of her condition.]] | [[File:Joseph Anton Koch 006.jpg|thumb|375px|''Noah's Thank Offering'' (c. 1803) by [[Joseph Anton Koch]]. Noah builds an altar to the Lord after being delivered from the Flood; God sends the rainbow as a sign of his covenant ([[Book of Genesis|Genesis]] 8–9).]] |} In contemporary visual art, the rainbow often appears as well, notably in Peter Coffin's ''Untitled (Rainbow)'', 2005,Announcement on e-flux http://www.artandeducation.net/announcement/utah-museum-of-fine-arts-presents-the-smithson-effect/ and in Ugo Rondinone's ''Hell, Yes!'', 2001.[[Ugo Rondinone]] Like many other cultural references to the rainbow, these either emphasize the possible sublimity of the natural world or the cheerfulness, joy, and celebration often culturally associated with a profusion of colors. In 2012, American artist, [[Michael Jones McKean]] created a large-scale artwork, [http://www.therainbow.org/ ''The Rainbow''].http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/05/23/michael-jones-mckean_n_1539378.html The project created, impart, a fully sustainable prismatic rainbow using thousands of gallons of pressurized harvested rainwater, at times stretching several city blocks in size.{{cite web |url=http://michaeljonesmckean.com/interview-gaddy.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-12-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217224432/http://michaeljonesmckean.com/interview-gaddy.html |archivedate=2013-12-17 |df= }} ==Literature== Judith Bauer Stamper's 1987 Find Your Fate book "Jem and The Holograms #3: The Secret of Rainbow Island ", involves the reader in saving Rainbow Island, a tropical island that frequently has rainbows. American legend retelling ''The Rough Face Girl" involves the heroines seeing an invisible Chief, who wears a rainbow as a sash. Stephen King's 1985 book '[[It (novel)|It]]'' features a scene where Ben Hanscom sees a spray bow while fighting with Henry Bowers in The Barrens, and comments on finding gold at the end of it. The 1983 ''[[Care Bears]] '' book "A Sister for Ben" involves Cheer Bear, whose tummy symbol is a rainbow, telling Ben he will see a rainbow when his sister says her first word. Dan Piraro's comic strip ''[[Bizarro (comic strip)|Bizarro]]'' featured a 2008 cartoon about fictional pirate Rainbowbeard in response to Proposition 8. The rainbow inspires metaphor and simile. [[Virginia Woolf]] in ''[[To the Lighthouse]]'' highlights the transience of life and Man's mortality through Mrs Ramsey's thought, :''"it was all as ephemeral as a rainbow"'' [[William Wordsworth|Wordsworth's]] 1802 poem "[[My Heart Leaps Up]]" begins: :''My heart leaps up when I behold'' ::''A rainbow in the sky:'' :''So was it when my life began;'' :''So is it now I am a man;'' :''So be it when I shall grow old,'' ::''Or let me die!...'' The [[Isaac Newton|Newtonian]] deconstruction of the rainbow is said to have provoked [[John Keats]] to lament in his 1820 poem "[[s:Lamia|Lamia]]": :''Do not all charms fly'' :''At the mere touch of cold philosophy?'' :''There was an awful rainbow once in heaven:'' :''We know her woof, her texture; she is given'' :''In the dull catalogue of common things.'' :''Philosophy will clip an Angel's wings,'' :''Conquer all mysteries by rule and line,'' :''Empty the haunted air, and gnomed mine –'' :''Unweave a rainbow'' In contrast to this is [[Richard Dawkins]]; talking about his book ''[[Unweaving the Rainbow]]: Science, Delusion and the Appetite for Wonder'':
"My title is from [[Keats]], who believed that [[Isaac Newton|Newton]] had destroyed all the poetry of the rainbow by reducing it to the prismatic colours. Keats could hardly have been more wrong, and my aim is to guide all who are tempted by a similar view, towards the opposite conclusion. Science is, or ought to be, the inspiration for great poetry."

Her horse Starlite has a rainbow mane and tail. * The Rainbow Warrior was a spaceship featured in the 1983 series ''[[He-Man and the Masters of the Universe]] '' episode "The Rainbow Warrior". *The film ''[[The Serpent and the Rainbow (film)|The Serpent and the Rainbow]] '' *In ''[[The Care Bears]] '' Cheer Bear has a rainbow as a tummy symbol and True Heart Bear and Noble Heart Horse have pastel rainbow hair. *''[[Space Cases]] '' character Catalina has rainbows hair. *[[Double Rainbow (viral video)]] ==Computer games== * In ''[[Rainbow Islands: The Story of Bubble Bobble 2|Rainbow Islands]]'', a 1987 arcade game, rainbows are used for fighting enemies. ==Flags== {{Main|Rainbow flag}} Rainbow flags tend to be used as a sign of a new era, of hope, or of social change. {{Infobox book | name = Solar Energy Perspectives | image = Solar Energy Perspectives.jpg | caption = | author = Cédric Philibert | title_orig = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = | language = | series = | subject = | genre = | publisher = [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]]/[[International Energy Agency]] | pub_date = 2011 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = 228 pp. | awards = | isbn = 9264124578 | oclc = 767906899 | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Solar Energy Perspectives''''' is a 2011 book by the [[International Energy Agency]].[http://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/Solar_Energy_Perspectives2011.pdf Solar Energy Perspectives: full text (free download)] [[Solar energy]] technologies come in various forms – [[solar heating]], [[solar photovoltaics]], [[solar thermal electricity]] – and can make considerable contributions to solving some of the most urgent problems the world now faces:
The development of affordable, inexhaustible and clean solar energy technologies will have huge longer-term benefits. It will increase countries’ energy security through reliance on an indigenous, inexhaustible and mostly import-independent resource, enhance sustainability, reduce pollution, lower the costs of mitigating climate change, and keep fossil fuel prices lower than otherwise. These advantages are global. Hence the additional costs of the incentives for early deployment should be considered learning investments; they must be wisely spent and need to be widely shared.
''Solar Energy Perspectives'' builds upon past analyses of solar energy deployment contained in the ''World Energy Outlook'', ''Energy Technology Perspectives'' and several IEA ''Technology Roadmaps''. It aims at "offering an updated picture of current technology trends and markets, as well as new analyses on how solar energy technologies for electricity, heat and fuels can be used in the various energy consuming sectors, now and in the future". ==See also== *''[[Deploying Renewables 2011]]'' *[[The Third Industrial Revolution (book)|The Third Industrial Revolution]] *''[[The Clean Tech Revolution]]'' *[[List of books about renewable energy]] *[[Mark Z. A '''static synchronous compensator''' ('''STATCOM'''), also known as a '''static synchronous condenser''' ('''STATCON''')<ref name="IEEE Conference Publication 2017-1">{{cite web | title=A state of the art STATCON for instantaneous VAr compensation and harmonic suppression to enhance power quality | website=IEEE Conference Publication | date=2017-12-18 | url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/1259331/ | access-date=2017-12-26}}</ref><ref name="IEEE Conference Publication 2017-2">{{cite web | title=Network simulation with STATCON devices to avoid voltage collapse in the interconnected system | website=IEEE Conference Publication | date=2017-12-18 | url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/1558917/ | access-date=2017-12-26}}</ref>, is a regulating device used on [[alternating current]] electricity transmission networks. It is based on a [[power electronics]] voltage-source converter and can act as either a source or sink of reactive [[AC power]] to an electricity network. If connected to a source of power it can also provide active [[AC power]]. It is a member of the [[flexible AC transmission system|FACTS]] family of devices. It is inherently modular and electable.
These compensators are also usable to reduce voltage fluctuations.<ref name="IEEE Conerence Publication 2017-3">{{cite web | title=STATCOM, an efficient means for flicker mitigation | website=IEEE Conference Publication | date=2017-12-18 | url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/747380/ | access-date=2017-12-26}}</ref>
==Uses== Usually a STATCOM is installed to support electricity networks that have a poor [[power factor]] and often poor [[voltage regulation]].<ref name="IEEE Conference Publication 2017">{{cite web | title=Voltage regulation by grid connected PV-STATCOM | website=IEEE Conference Publication | date=2017-12-18 | url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/8081136/ | access-date=2017-12-26}}</ref> There are however, other uses, the most common use is for voltage stability.
==Construction and operation== A STATCOM is a voltage source converter (VSC)-based device, with the voltage source behind a reactor. The voltage source is created from a DC [[capacitor]] and therefore a STATCOM has very little active power capability. However, its active power capability can be increased if a suitable energy storage device is connected across the DC capacitor. The reactive power at the terminals of the STATCOM depends on the amplitude of the voltage source. For example, if the terminal voltage of the VSC is higher than the AC voltage at the point of connection, the STATCOM generates reactive current; conversely, when the amplitude of the voltage source is lower than the AC voltage, it absorbs reactive power.<ref name="IEEE Conference Publication 2017-4">{{cite web | title=Voltage profile improvements of Mosul city ring system by STATCOM reactive power control | website=IEEE Conference Publication | date=2017-12-18 | url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/6490654/ | access-date=2017-12-26}}</ref> The response time of a STATCOM is shorter than that of a [[static VAR compensator]] (SVC)<ref name="Hingorani Gyugyi 2017">{{cite web | last=Hingorani | first=Narain G. | last2=Gyugyi | first2=Laszlo | title=Static Shunt Compensators: SVC and STATCOM | website=Wiley-IEEE Press Books | date=2017-12-18 | doi=10.1109/9780470546802.ch5 | url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/articleDetails.jsp?arnumber=5264273&queryText=statcom&ranges=1977_2002_Year | access-date=2017-12-26}}</ref>, mainly due to the fast switching times provided by the [[Insulated gate bipolar transistor|IGBT]]s of the voltage source converter. The STATCOM also provides better reactive power support at low AC voltages than an SVC, since the reactive power from a STATCOM decreases linearly with the AC voltage (as the current can be maintained at the rated value even down to low AC voltage).
==Similar devices== A [[static var compensator]] can also be used for voltage stability. However, a STATCOM has better characteristics than an SVC. When the system voltage drops sufficiently to force the STATCOM output current to its ceiling, its maximum reactive output current will not be affected by the voltage magnitude. Therefore, it exhibits constant current characteristics when the voltage is low under the limit. In contrast the SVC's reactive output is proportional to the square of the voltage magnitude. This makes the provided reactive power decrease rapidly when voltage decreases, thus reducing its stability. In addition, the speed of response of a STATCOM is faster than that of an SVC and the harmonic emission is lower, however STATCOMs typically exhibit higher losses and may be more expensive than SVCs, so the (older) SVC technology is still widespread.
